block.p: Everybody agrees that sport utility vehicles are hazardous to those riding in cars, but Robert Frank's suggestion for imposing a weight tax on these truck-like vehicles is not the answer (''Feeling Crash-Resistant in an S.U.V.,'' Op-Ed, May 16).

Everybody agrees that sport utility vehicles are hazardous to those riding in cars, but Robert Frank's suggestion for imposing a weight tax on these truck-like vehicles is not the answer (''Feeling Crash-Resistant in an S.U.V.,'' Op-Ed, May 16).
Those who could afford the tax would still drive an S.U.V. Those who could not would have to sacrifice safety, and the number of lighter vehicles on the road would be increased.
Worse, the S.U.V. might become even more of a status symbol.

The federal government should have imposed adequate safety and performance standards on S.U.V.'s long ago, and it is a scandal that it took the chairman of the Ford Motor Company to spotlight the problem.
The solution is a public-relations effort to achieve a shift in public attitudes as we saw on smoking. S.U.V.'s must be seen as unfashionable, selfish indulgences that are hazardous to public safety.
MALCOLM W. BOYD Sandy, Ore., May 17, 2000
